page.title: 05New Forest Pigs.
page.content: Pigs and the New Forest have a "love/hate" relationship.If pigs were allowed to roam the Forest throughout the year they could cause considerable damage by rooting with their snouts. As they root up the grass looking for seeds and fleshy roots of plants they can damage large amounts of Forest grassland. To get over this problem pig owners who have the right to pannage are given permission to let their pigs into the Forest for not less than 60 days a year.The pigs have to have a ring put through their snouts to stop them rooting.The "pannage season" is usually between October and November,the Deputy Surveyor of the Forestry Commission deciding the dates. Owners of ponies are grateful to the pigs-acorns are poisonous for ponies.
